ca.uqac.lif.cep.io

Class StreamReader

  • java.lang.Object
    • ca.uqac.lif.cep.Processor
      • ca.uqac.lif.cep.SingleProcessor
        • ca.uqac.lif.cep.tmf.Source
          • ca.uqac.lif.cep.io.StreamReader
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Contextualizable, Cloneable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    HttpReader

    public class StreamReader
extends Source
    Reads chunks of data from an input source. These chunks are returned as events in the form of strings.
    Author:
    sylvain

    • Field Detail

      • m_fis

        protected InputStream m_fis
        The input stream from which data will be read

      • s_chunkSize

        protected static final int s_chunkSize
        The size of chunks. The PipeReader will try to read this number of bytes every time it queries the underlying input source. Setting it to a too small value will cause the reader to loop uselessly to process tiny bits of the string. Setting it to a too large value (i.e. 1 MB) has an equally adverse effect. Experimentally, a sweet spot seems to be 16 kB.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • m_sleepIntervalMs

        protected int m_sleepIntervalMs
        The interval that the reader should sleep (i.e. wait) before polling the pipe again in the loop. This interval is broken down in milliseconds + nanoseconds; nano should not be over 999,999 (otherwise add 1 to milli). You should tweak these values to avoid clogging your CPU (setting them to 0 will hike it to 100%) while not lagging on the input trace.

      • m_sleepIntervalNs

        protected int m_sleepIntervalNs

      • END_CHARACTER

        public static final String END_CHARACTER
        Character indicating the closing of a pipe. By default, we use ASCII 4, which is traditionally interpreted as the end of transmission character (EOT). This has no effect when the underlying input is not a pipe.

      • m_isFile

        protected boolean m_isFile
        Remembers whether the underlying input stream is a file or a pipe. This changes the condition to test to determine if there is more data to read.

      • m_returnCode

        protected int m_returnCode
        The pipe reader carries a "return code" that indicates under which conditions the thread has stopped (normal end or error of some kind)
